t: Habakkuk 1
The*p prophecy that Habakkuk the prophet received.
Habakkuk’s Complaint
How*pn long, Lord,*s must I call for help, but*ld you do not listen? Or*ln cry out to you, “Violence!” but*ld you do not save?
Why*ln do you make me look at injustice? Why*ld do you tolerate wrongdoing? Destruction*ln and violence are before me; there*ld is strife, and conflict abounds.
Therefore*ln the law is paralyzed, and*ld justice never prevails. The*ln wicked hem in the righteous, so*ld that justice is perverted.
The Lord’s Answer
“Look*pn at the nations and watch— and*ld be utterly amazed. For*ln I am going to do something in your days that*ld you would not believe, even*ld if you were told.
I*ln am raising up the Babylonians, that*ld ruthless and impetuous people, who*ln sweep across the whole earth to*ld seize dwellings not their own.
They*ln are a feared and dreaded people; they*ld are a law to themselves and*ld promote their own honor.
Their*ln horses are swifter than leopards, fiercer*ld than wolves at dusk. Their*ln cavalry gallops headlong; their*ld horsemen come from afar. They*ln fly like an eagle swooping to devour;
they*ld all come intent on violence. Their*ln hordes advance like a desert wind and*ld gather prisoners like sand.
They*ln mock kings and*ld scoff at rulers. They*ln laugh at all fortified cities; by*ld building earthen ramps they capture them.
Then*ln they sweep past like the wind and go on— guilty*ld people, whose own strength is their god.”
Habakkuk’s Second Complaint
Lord,*spn are you not from everlasting? My*ld God, my Holy One, you will never die. You,*ln Lord,*s have appointed them to execute judgment; you,*ld my Rock, have ordained them to punish.

Your*ln eyes are too pure to look on evil; you*ld cannot tolerate wrongdoing. Why*ln then do you tolerate the treacherous? Why*ld are you silent while the wicked swallow*ld up those more righteous than themselves?
You*ln have made people like the fish in the sea, like*ld the sea creatures that have no ruler.
The*ln wicked foe pulls all of them up with hooks, he*ld catches them in his net, he*ln gathers them up in his dragnet; and*ld so he rejoices and is glad.
Therefore*ln he sacrifices to his net and*ld burns incense to his dragnet, for*ln by his net he lives in luxury and*ld enjoys the choicest food.
Is*ln he to keep on emptying his net, destroying*ld nations without mercy?
